poem:
**Oasis at Murrayfield**

In Edinburgh, the night unfolds,  
where the echoes of youth unroll,  
middle-aged hearts bound in chorus,  
strumming the air with songs of old.  
Yet the council speaks of room and drink,  
of fans who dance on the brink,  
forgetting how music can cradle souls,  
and rowdy love in twilight clinks.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Edinburgh council’s attitude to Oasis fans ‘stinks’, says Liam Gallagher Liam Gallagher has criticised Edinburgh council bosses after Oasis fans attending three sellout concerts at Murrayfield Stadium were described as mainly “rowdy” “middle-aged men” who “take up more room” and would drink to “medium to high intoxication”. The Scottish Sun said it had obtained safety briefing documents through freedom of information requests, before the reunion gigs on 8, 9 and 12 August. In them, officials". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
